div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7237] ALEXANDRIA, TUESDAY, JULY 11, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p: This Company's system of submarine telegraph cables is the most direct and quickest means of communication from Egypt to Europe, North and South America, East, South and West Africa, India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.
To secure quick transmission, telegrams should be marked Via Eastern.
For latest average time to London, see daily bulletin in this paper.
STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo, Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Head Office. London.

div.head: The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

OUTWARDS to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Oruba" will leave Suez about July 14 | R.M.S "Orotava" will leave Suez about July 28.
HOMEWARDS to NAPLES MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY
R.M.S. "Oroya" will leave Port Said about July 18 | R.M.S. “Ortona" will leave Port Said about August 1
Egyptian Government Officials allowed a rebate of 15% off the above fares.

Return tickets no longer issued, but passengers paying full fare in one direction allowed abatement of 1/3 fare back if return voyage be within 4 months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within 8 months of arrival.

S.S. Derbyshire 6,635 tons, leaves about July 20.
S.S. Lancashire 4,244 tons, leaves about August 3.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON. Departures from Port Said.
S.S. Staffordshire 6,005 tons leaves about July 12.
S.S. Worcestershire 7,160 tons, leaves about July 26.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
FAST BRITISH PASSENGER STEAMERS
GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency. 31-12-904

S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, July 15, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.

Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook’s Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Paris, London, Naples, Rome. Arrival Trieste Wednesday noon connecting with Vienna Express (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and expresses to Italy and Germany.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste

(Departures from Suez) To Aden, Bombay, Colombo, Penang, Singapore, Hong-Kong, Shanghai, Yokohama, Kobé about July 5 and August 4. To Aden, Karachi, and Bombay accelerated service about August 18. To Aden, Karachi, Bombay, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about July 20.

div.head:
IMPORTANT NOTICE.
MARTELL COGNAC.
div.p: M. H. DEMIRGIAN BEY, General Agent for this important House, warns the public to beware of Imitations, and to examine the labels, corks, and capsules.

div.p: First Class Hotel. Modern in all respects.
Fire-proof, Drained to the Sea, Lifts, Electric Light, English and French Billiards, Fresh and Salt Water Baths.

div.head: Hall's Sanitary Washable Distemper

An artistic wall covering.
This celebrated water paint is made in two qualities for Inside and Outside work

HALL’S SANITARY WASHABLE DISTEMPER is rapidly superseding wall papers in all tastefully furnished homes. It is made in 70 artistic tints, and only requires the addition of water to make it ready for use. It is quickly and easily applied with a whitewash brush, with half the labour and at one third the cost of paint. HALL’S DISTEMPER ensures cleanliness, and is pleasing to the eye. It appeals alike to artistic and practical house decoration. HALL’S DISTEMPER is of special value in hot climates. Owing to its cool, pleasing colours, great weather-resisting and germ-destroying properties, it lends itself to every kind of wall, wood, brick or stone coating, possessing all the advantages of paint, colour- wash, and disinfectant at one third the cost of oil paint. div.head: The Seasonable Complaint. Laxitive is the Remedy.
div.p: Almost everyone, at the end of summer, FEELS WILTED AND RUN DOWN. We wonder how we stood the heat of January and February so well, only to collapse when the weather is appreciably cooler. The reason is that the Summer strain is just beginning to tell on us. We need to CLEAR THE SYSTEM OF POISONOUS WASTES, and to stimulate the Liver and Kidneys into action again. IN CHOOSING AN APERIENT we look for certainty of result, gentleness of action, and palatableness. div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber’s address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE can be obtained in London at our office, 36, New Broad Street, E.C., and also at Messrs. May & Williams 160, Piccadilly, W.
THE “EGYPTIAN GAZETTE” IS PRINTED ON PAPER MANUFACTURED AND SUPPLIED BY THE LONDON PAPER MILLS Co., LIMITED (SALES OFFICE: 27, CANNON STREET, E.C.)
The Egyptian Gazette
An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
TUESDAY, JULY 11, 1905.

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL
div.p: Bulkeley, Ramleh.
Ten minutes from Alexandria. First-Class in every respect Very moderate charges. Bulkeley is the fashionable English quarter. Visitors fron Cairo alight at Sidi Gaber Station.
G. AQUILINA, Proprieter.

div.head: NATIONAL DEFENCE. A DEBATE IN UPPER HOUSE. MR. BALFOUR CRITICISED. LORD “BOBS” AND CONSCRIPTION.

div.p: During the debate on National Defence in the House of Lords Mr. Balfour’s statement of the 11th of May was severely criticised. Lord Roberts said that the lessons of the South African war were already^ forgotten. He had no hesitation in saying that the army is as absolutely unfitted and unprepared for war now as it was then. The nation must choose between conscription and universal training. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE “ENTENTE CORDIALE.” BRITISH FLEET AT BREST.

div.p: The preparations for the reception of the British fleet, which will arrive to-day, have just been completed. The rejoicings promise to constitute a record in international naval courtesies. The programme of official and private festivities is so huge that there will hardly be an hour during the whole week that will not be accounted for.
There are evidences on every side that the visit is most popular. (Reuter.)
The British squadron has arrived in order to assist at the fêtes given in its honor. Its arrival was cheered by those on shore. (Havas.)
The British fleet arrived this afternoon. There was a remarkable demonstration of welcome by immense crowds ashore and afloat.(R.)

Chamber of Deputies. — M. Rouvier announced that France has accepted the Morocco Conference and that Germany recognised French rights and interests. M. Rouvier’s words were greeted with unanimous applause. (Havas.)

M. Rouvier announced in the Chamber that France and Germany have agreed to an international conference on the lines mentioned yesterday. He stated that the missions at Fes will be recalled when the conference meets. Germany has not raised the question of the Anglo-French nor the Franco-Spanish agreements, which are not mentioned in the negotiations. (Reuter.)
The Socialist organ “Vorwaerts” has publishd M. Jaures's lecture textually. The tone is moderate and most friendly to Germany.
There is a notable warmth the reference to the Anglo-French entente, declaring that “we shall resist to our last breath any attempt to entangle us in hostile action with Great Britain.” (Reuter.)

div.head: THE PEACE COMMISSION. PLACE OF MEETING.
div.p: The peace plenipotentiaries will meet at Portsmouth in the State of New Hampshire. (Reuter.)

div.head: JAPANESE LOAN ISSUED.
div.p: The Japanese loan has been issued.(R )

div.head: JAPANESE ESPIONAGE CASE.
div.p: M. Bougouin, mentioned in despatches of the 10th of May, has been sentenced to 10 4 years’ hard labour, and the interpreter Maki to 8. (Reuter)

div.head: CORRUPTION IN WASHINGTON. LEAKAGE OF COTTON REPORTS.
div.p: Owing to constant complaints of the leakage of cotton reports to brokers, the Government has instituted an enquiry which has resulted in the dismissal of the leading statistician at the Department of Agriculture. (Reuter)

div.head: FRENCH SUBMARINE DISASTER.
div.p: It is not believed that it will be possible to raise the submarine before some days. The Minister of Marine has arrived and has gone for a long submarine trip in a vessel of the same type. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE CANADIAN NAVY.
div.p: The disorders mentioned on the 8th inst. have been settled. A new Crew has been embarked. (Reuter.)

div.head: Rains
div.p: in the Kassala to be late.

div.head: The New Anti-Rabic Institute,
div.p: it is expected, will be completed by the end of the year.

div.head: Agricultural Shows
div.p: are to be held in the Fayoum and at Mansourah in September and October next.

div.head: Little Girl Drowned.
div.p: A child, named Um el Saâd, four years of age, was accidentally drowned in a masraf at Boghos Pasha’s ezbeh.

div.head: Stray and Ownerless Dogs
div.p: found in the Saida Zeynab quarter of Cairo during the night of Wednesday and at daylight on Thurs day will be poisoned by the police.

div.head: Defrauding the Revenue.
div.p: A man named Antonio Carabot was arrested yesterday with a quantity of silk thread in his possession which he was attempting to smuggle.

div.head: P. W. D.
div.p: Sir Wm. Garstin’s Report for 1904 on the Public Works Department is in the hands of the printer, and will be published in October next.

div.head: Suez Canal.
div.p: 10 vessels passed through the Canal on the 7th inst., 8 of which were British, 1 French, 1 German. The day’s receipts were frs. 293,573.11, making the total from the 1st inst. frs. 2,126,168.89.

div.head: The Plague
div.p: Yesterday’s bulletin records a fatal case at Alexandria, the victim being a native fisherman who was found dead at his house at Khattabieh. A fatal case is reported from Ashmoun, a death from Damanhour, and a recovery from Menouf.

div.head: Theatre Regulations.
div.p: The Ministry of the Interior has sent the new regulations for theatres to the Ministry of Justice in order to be submitted to the Mixed Court of Appeal for its approval, which cannot be given till after the vacation.

div.head: Mosque for Paris
div.p: M. Lion Lambeir, a French merchant, has decided to construct a mosque in Paris, and has asked the French Government to grant him a site for the purpose. A fatwa has been signed by the rector of El Azhar University approving the project.

div.head: An Absconding Clerk.
div.p: M. Leonardo Golisti, advocate, has informed the Attarin police that his clerk, named Abdulla Hozalli el Shami, to whom he had entrusted a cheque of £50 in order to pay costs in a law case at the Mixed Tribunal, has absconded with the money. _

div.head: Another Case of Embezzlement.
div.p: The Attarin police have also received notice from M. George Maisokis, director of the Kafr-el-Zayat Cotton Co., that a man named Ahmed Mursi had cashed a cheque for L.E. 61 with the Anglo-Egyptian Bank, and had absconded with the money. _

div.head: Suspicious Death.
div.p: The Alexandria Gouvernorat has been informed by the Minet el Bassal police that a man named Moh. El Said Rizk, who had died in his house, was found, by the medical officer who was called in, to have a severe wound on the forehead. His relatives, when questioned, said that the deceased suffered from hysteria, which caused the injuries that resulted in his death.
The Earl of Cromer was one of the guests at a dinner party given on Saturday week by the Prince of Wales in honor of Prince Arisugawa of Japan.
Sir Wm. Garstin left Cairo this morning for Port Said, where he will embark on the P.& O. S.S. Britannia.
Mr. E. B. Gould I.S.O., H.B.M’s Consul- General at Alexandria, and Mrs. Gould are leaving for Europe on Saturday next.
Mr. A. D. Alban, H.B.M’s Consul in Cairo, and Mrs. Alban leave for Europe by the French steamer on Friday.

Two marriages of local interest take place to-morrow in London, one at St. Peter’s, Eaton square, where Major D. K. E. Hall, A.S.C. (Egyptian Army), will be married to Mrs. R. Howe Davis, of Sandy Hill, Crafton, California; and the other at St. George’s, Hanover square, where Captain C. W. Maclean, Lancashire Fusiliers, will wed Miss Gladys Royle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Royle, of Ghezifeh, Cairo. On the 18th, Mr. Horace Rumbold, second secretary at the British Agency, eldest son of Sir Horace Rumbold, formerly British Ambassador to Austria, marries Miss Etheldred Fane, daughter of the late Sir Edmund Fane, British Minister to Denmark.
Halil Hamada Pasha, Director of Customs at Alexandria, who has been staying at Constantinople, has now left for Western Europe.
We are glad to hear that Mr. G. de Beaupuis, manager of the Banco di Roma in Alex andria, is making very satisfactory progress and hopes to return to Egypt at the end of the month.
Mr. H. W. Tite, chief inspector of the International Sleeping Car Company, arrived in Cairo yesterday from Paris. He will shortly leave for Cyprus, where Mrs. Tite is passing the summer.

div.head: STATE RAILWAY CONTRACTS. AN OFFICIAL DEMENTI.
div.p: Statements having appeared in certain newspapers to the effect that the German Diplomatic Agent in Egypt had protested against an alleged change in the system of placing railway contracts by international competition, we are authorised to state that the German Diplomatic Agent has informed the authorities concerned that no complaints whatever have been made to him.

We are further authorised to state that no change of policy has occurred, but exceptions to the rule are now, as they were formerly, committed when it is clearly to the public’s advantage to dispense with competition, and owing to the very rapid increase of traffic within the last twelve months, the number of exceptional eases which have recently occurred has been large. This has no doubt given rise to the rumours alluded to. w

The exceptional cases mentioned have as a rule taken the form of giving orders in extension of their contract to firms who have been successful in previous competitions, in order to avoid the delay necessitated by a fresh competition.

div.head: THE GRAND MUFTI.
div.p: We regret to learn this morning that the condition of the Grand Mufti has taken another turn for the worse. Little hope is now entertained of his recovery.

div.head: ESNEH BARRAGE.
div.p: The Public Works Department expect to commence the construction of the Esneh Barrage next year. Tenders will be invited in October next.

div.head: AMERICAN COTTON.
div.p: The following telegram has been received m Mr. Price of New York by Mr. G. L. Sursock:— “Market possibly entitled to some reaction, bat doubtful ; it is on its certain way to twelve cents in my opinion.”

div.head: DEAR CEREALS.
div.p: The country is suffering considerably this year from the high price of cereals. Durrah and beans, which form the principal ingredient in the diet of the fellah, have reached the price of P,T. 9 to 10 per keila. In spite of the excellent barley crop in the Mariout district, for which the abundant rains of last winter are responsible, the price of barley has risen to from P.T. 63 to 65 per ardeb, against an average of P.T. 45 per ardeb in 1904, when the rain crop was to all intents and purposes non-existent The English and Con­tinental breweries have bought up a very large proportion of this year’s crop, and the barley from the rain belt is evidently in as high request among brewers as ever. The present price of these cereals makes the feeding of horses and cattle a very costly affair. The bersim is over and the poorer owners of cattle and horses are sometimes obliged to give their beasts half rations.

div.head: MORTGAGES IN EGYPT.
div.p: It is stated that the Land Bank of Egypt has announced that it will issue no further loans on mortgages till the end of September. This bank has already placed upwards of £1,300,000 on similar loans since its founda­tion six months ago. The other mortgage-banks are only accepting on an average about 5 per cent, of the transactions proposed. The natural result of this action on their part is the growth of a certain uneasiness among land-owners, who find great difficulty in obtaining the money required for the exploitation of their lands. The Agricultural Bank, of course, con­fines its operations to the small cultivator.

div.head: PORT OF ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: During the half-year ended June 30 the number of vessels of all nationalities which entered the port of Alexandria was 856, of which number 367 were British. Other nationalities were represented as follows: — Italian 92, Greek 81, Austrian 77, French 59, German 54, Ottoman 49, Russian 48, Belgian 12, Swedish 8, Norwegian 2, Spanish 2, American 2, Dutch 2, Danish 1.

Of the 367 vessels which flew the British flag it is interesting to note that 54 belonged to the Khedivial Mail Line, 48 to Bell’s Asia Minor Company, 40 to the Prince Line, 36 to the Ellerman Lines, 20 to the Moss Line, 12 to the Westcott and Lawrence Line, and 5 to the P. and O. Company. Of the 92 Italian steamers, 65 belonged to the Florio-Rubattino Company. 51 of the 59 French vessels belonged to the Messageries Maritimes, 68 of the 77 Austrian to the Austrian Lloyd Company, 30 of the German to the Deutsche Levantie Line and 23 to the Norddeutsoher Lloyd. During the six months four men-of-war (two British, one German, and one Italian) paid a visit to this port.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Scottish Prince arrived in Man­chester from Alexandria on Saturday last.
The S.S. Avon (Ellerman Line) arrived at Liverpool from Alexandria on Tuesday.
The S.S. Bulgarian (Ellerman Line) will sail hence for Liverpool on Wednesday.

div.head: BRITISH TRADE IN EGYPT. MR. FREEMAN’S REPORT.
div.p: In his report on the trade of Alexandria for 1904 Mr. Vice-Consul Freeman remarks ;— The answer to the question why the United Kingdom is, or at any rate seems to be, grad­ually losing the largest share in respect of the total imports is perhaps to be found in the wonderfully prosperous condition of the country.i, the greater attention that it consequently, attracts among Continental manufacturers and merchants, and in the keener desire aroused on 9 their part to enter so tempting a market. The contributions of countries other than those specified in the table have more than doubled in the space of four years. Postal parcels and the various goods included under the heading of “Other imports” have likewise doubled in four years. The expansion is spread over all categories and almost all items, and the stock inquiry : “Where are there openings for British trade ?” can best be answered with the one word “everywhere.” But at the same time I can only repeat the 8took advice to manufacturers, jointly or singly, to have agents on the spot and to send more travellers. As the representative of a group of British firms remarked to me, the native tastes may not change, the same class of goods may be in demand for years, but nevertheless local requirements should be studied at the outset, and regular, periodical visits are necessary to ensure a hold on the market. The agents at Alexandria of a British firm dealing in carpenters’ and blacksmiths’ tools and also in Sheffield goods in general wrote to this Con­sulate as follows:—“The difficulty with our principals arises from the fact that the native does not use the same tools as the British workman. Many modifications and additions have consequently to be made so as to adapt the tools to what is required on our markets. If it were a question of a few articles only, the difficulty could easily be overcome by sending home samples ; but as there are a thousand and probably more lines that have to be attended to you will easily understand how impossible it is for an agent who is neither a carpenter nor a blacksmith to give them all the particulars they want. We there­fore suggested that they should send out either one of the partners in their firm or a competent traveller, who, with our help, might secure the first orders. What we have to complain of most in the firms at home is that, although oar markets are invaded by an army 'of foreign travellers, they (the British firms) do not take the trouble or care to incur the expense of sending out competent men to see What others are doing. We may give you as an instance the case of Messrs whose turnover with us was very small until they decided to send out one of the partners of the firm. They are now doing many more thousands than they did hundreds.”

Another British commercial traveller told me that his quotation for certain goods was 18s. per cwt. (If. 16s. per 100 kilos.) with three months’ credit, while the German quotation, thanks partly to the drawback in Germany, was 25 fr. (1/.) per 100 kilos., with six months’ credit. The British article was of course better, and some people preferred it, but it was not, as the priced would seem to show, worth nearly twice as much as the German article. With such competition as this to face, merchandise, however excellent in itself, can scarcely be left to speak for itself with any prospect of success. I hear of machinery being bought in the United Kingdom by German firms and sold at Alex­andria more cheaply than if it were imported direct. Here again there is surely scope for the energies of a British traveller.

Inquiries of all kinds are received at this Consulate in ever increasing numbers, and it is becoming almost impossible to answer them all. The prospects and possibilities of this trade and of that trader the restrictions and regulations to which they are subject, a description of the articles already in the market, —such inquiries cannot be usefully answered except after long and careful study of the conditions affecting each particular trade, and this study a Consul has no time to undertake.

div.head: FRENCH FETE.
div.p: Preparations for the celebration in Cairo of the French fête on Friday next are almost completed. A large and well-decorated triumphal arch has been erected at the Boulac entrance of the Esbekieh Gardens, and this will be illuminated on the night of the 14th. A wooden pavilion has been erected in the gardens for the official receptions and a stage has also b3en erected for a variety entertainment which will be given by the troupe of the “Nouveautés.” The gardens are gaily decorated with flags and promise to look most effective when lit up by the numerous Chinese lanterns and electric globes which are hung in every direction. The bands of the 2nd Royal lnniskilling Fusiliers and the Egyptian Cavalry will perform alternately throughout the even­ing, and there will also be a grand display of fireworks.

All entrances to the gardens except the Boulac one will be closed and this will be opened at 9 p.m. The officers of the Egyptian Army and the Army of Ocupation have accepted the invitation of the committee to assist at the festivities.
BECK & CO’S PILSENER BEER BREMEN. MASS HO HOHWT COMPETITION FOB QUALITY. N.B.—Inferior Brands now bring offwad to Mao* agar of certain good writs. Beware el svflly Higessd eemgetltow rawing

div.head: NOTES FROM SUAKIN. FEVER ON THE INCREASE.
div.p: The weather is becoming more oppressive than ever, owing to the hot khamseen winds. Fever is daily on the increase, both among the natives and Europeans, especially among the railway people. The latest victim in hospital is Mr. W. H. Bailey, Inspector of Bridges, Suakin-Atbara Line, who is, however, pro­gressing favorably towards recovery.

The following passengers are leaving by the S.S. Dakahlieh to-day, viz., Mr. Smart, chief storekeeper, Suakin Railway, who is being invalided home to England, Mr. Fulton and Mr. Finlay, also of the Suakin-Atbara Rail­ways, who are likewise returning to England invalided as unfit for Suakin.
Mr. Ward, chief engineer of the Sudan Government steamer Hawk, having resigned his appointment with the Sudan Government, also leaves to-day by the Dakahlieh.

Dr. Crispin, senior medical officer, Suakin Moudirieh, is also a passenger by the S.S. Dakahlieh. He is going on three months’ leave of absence, which he will spend in England. Daring the absence of Dr. Crispin, Dr. Ibra­him Effendy Fahmy will act as S.M.O.

div.head: EGYPTIAN LAND AND GENERAL TRUST.
div.p: The report of the Egyptian Land and General Trust, Ltd., submitted to the statutory meeting on the 6th instant, states that with a view to spreading the company’s investments over as wide a field as possible, the directors are acquiring a large building area in the heart of Cairo, and their agent-general in Egypt, Mr. Hooker, who has recently been to London to confer with the board, has just left for Egypt to complete the arrangements, subject to the titles of the property proving satisfactory. If this business is concluded the directors have no hesitation in saying that it will be a most satis­factory investment for the company. The direc­tors are also on the point of completing the purchase of some very valuable budding land in Alexandria which has been strongly recommended to them by their local advisers. The directors feel that when these transactions are concluded the shareholders will have a considerable interest in the heart of the two most important cities in Egypt—namely, Cairo and Alexandria, which cannot fail to give most satisfactory results. In view of the growing importance of the Egyptian Mining industry, the directors are supporting on favorable terms the issue of the Egyptian Gold and Emerald Company, Ltd. In this they are acting in conjunction with the United African Explo­rations, Ltd. The Egyptian Gold and Emerald Company, Ltd., is formed to acquire what appears to be one of the most important mineral concessions in Egypt The concession comprises an area of some 3,000 square miles, and it is reported upon by responsible engineers as being rich in gold, silver, lead, copper and emerald mines. The directors have also before them various proposals, which are-likely to materialise shortly, for the development of sound and profitable business in other direc­tions. The Board have elected Mr. Charles H. Rigg as a director to represent his substantial financial interest in the company.
July 5 was fixed by the committee of the London Stock Exchange as a special settling day in Egyptian Land and General Trust, Limited, 200,000 shares of £1 each, 5s paid (Nos. 1 to 200,000).
KHEDIVIAL YACHT CLUB, REGATTA. The following is the handicap for the month of July:— Class I.

div.head: A. S. C.
div.p: The following programme of music will be played at the Skye Meeting on the A. S C. grounds on Saturday next:— 1 March—On guard o’er the Empire—Myd- 2 Overture—Juanita—Suppe [dleton 3 SoDg (Cornet Solo)—The Silver Path -Be van. 4 Piccolo Solo - Playful Kittens—Young 5 Selection—The Belle of New York—Kerker 6 Serenade— —Leoncavallo 7 Valse—Tout Paris—Waldtenfel 8 Ein Albumblattr—Wagner 9 Selection—Die Puppen fee—Bayer 10 Danoe—The Coon s Holiday—Barns 9 Khedivial Anthem—God Save the King S. Dobs, Bandmaster, 2nd Royal Berkshire Regiment,

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondants, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit—within certain necessary limits—free discussion.

div.head: CAIRO STREET NUISANCE.
div.p: To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette.

Sir,—I should be greatly obliged if you would, through your columns, call the atten­tion of the Cairo police to another street nuisance which exists. At most of the junctions of two streets cabstands exist, and the cabmen appear to think that they have a right to stand in such a manner that the passage of pede­strians is entirely obstructed. The cabmen naturally wish to look for fares along both roads, and draw up their cabs accordingly, the general public have to go round them in the middle of the road, which has pos­sibly been recently watered. The stand opposite the Cafe Chicha is perhaps one of the worst cases in point There is always a policeman on duty at this place, but he does nothing to ameliorate the nuisance, and when complained to it is with the greatest difficulty that one can drive into his head that the cabman is in any way out of order. Personally, I invariably insist on the cab being removed. Sometimes I am met with abuse or stolid resistance, but, being fluent in the language, I finally get my way. Frequently the cabman returns to his former position immediately I have passed, and remains there. It surely would be an easy matter to explain to the policemen, either individually or collectively when on parade, the rights of pedestrians, or simpler still, to pat a red paint mark on the footpath indicating the limits of the cabstand. Apologising for troubling you,—I am, etc.,

div.head: REVOLTING CRUELTY AT PORT SAID.
div.p: To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette

Dear Sir,—At the hotels in Egypt collecting cards for the S. P. C. A. are in evidence for support, bat at Port Said at least they are not likely to get much as long as the dis­gusting scenes occur while cattle are being landed. The poor beasts are slung by the feet or horns, kept for hours without water, most likely from the port at which they embark, and on landing try to drink from the sea.

On Tuesday the passengers on a ship in quarantine (therefore unable to take steps) were entertained by the following exhibition of cruelty. A cow ran away from the herd and was chased out on the breakwater by three or four savages, her tail was twisted, she was stoned on the head and body with rocks of about 20 lbs., beaten unmercifully with battens 3 inches thick, sticks were thrust into her anus and vagina, she was thrown off the breakwater into the sea, a fall of 12 feet, dragged over the rocks that cut her hide, hauled up again in a most brutal fashion, her horns torn off and blood was streaming from her nostrils. This performance took about two hours. We are used to seeing acts of cruelty, but not such refined brutality as this. If the S. P. C. A. has a representative, he should be on the spot where these things happen or else he is not much use.—I am, etc.,

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: Encore sous l’influence de la liquidation de fin du mois, notre marché a débuté calme et insignifiant On s’attendait même à ce que cet état de marasme durut toute la semaine, lorsque l’heureuse issue des négociations franco-allemandes et la nomination définitive de ministres plénipotentiaires russo-japonais en vue de la paix ont remis à flot les bourses européennes ; ce qui a été d’autant plus facile que le capital abonde en Europe.

A tons ces motifs de hausse est encore venu s’ajouter un facteur important: la reprise soudaine et considérable des cotons à la suite du rapport du Bureau d’Agriculture de Washington sur les prévisions de la prochaine récolte. Sur notre place, pourtant, la spéculation continue à négliger les sociétés nouvelles pour concentrer toute son attention sur les anciennes, dites à tranche dorée. On a pu remarquer cette tendance chez un grand nombre de maisons financières de notre ville qui estiment sans doute que ces valeurs ont été trop dépréciées à l’occasion des derniers lancements de compagnies.

La valeur qui a donné lieu au plus fort mouvement est l’Agricole en raison de l’ouverture de la souscription des nouveaux titres à partir du 10 juillet jusqu’au 2 octobre. Ce fait a de suite attiré des acheteurs. Certains spéculateurs même, pensant que les nouveaux titres ne seraient livrés qu’au 2 octobre, c’est-à dire avec un trimestre de crédit, eurent bientôt fait de les pousser jusqu’à 9 13/16, tandis que l’ancienne émission ne dépassait pas 13 7/8 ; mais, à peine surent-ils que des certificats provisoires au porteur seraient mis en circulation dans un délai maximum d’un mois, qu’ils devinrent plus réservés : la nouvelle émission baissait du coup d’un quart de livre, tandis que l’ancienne avec droit montait de 1/16 à 1/8. L’ancienne avait débuté à 13 9/16 et touché un moment 14 1/16, elle clôture à 1315/16; la nouvelle finit à 9 9/16.
La Fondateur Agricole débute à 912 pour clôturer à 960 acheteurs.

Tout-à-fait calme d’abord à 28, la Daïra monte graduellement jusqu'à 28 1/2, pour réactionner aujourd’hui à 28 e/8. L’assemblée du Crédit Foncier Egyptien réunie au Caire samedi pour la liquidation de la Daïra a décidé, paraît-il, de payer à celle-ci la somme de

row.cell: Arrivals from Egypt S.S. "Flavian" 3147 and S.S. "Avon" 1798 bales of cotton.
Cotton day’s receipts at all U.-S. Ports
